This report was prepared by A. Iffland, Project Economist.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the Country Programming Mission in 2000, the Government of Papua New Guinea 
(PNG) and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) agreed that ADB will provide grant funding for a 
technical assistance (TA) in 2003 to prepare a project for possible ADB funding in 2004. The 
agreement  was  confirmed  during  the  Country  Programming  Mission  in  May  2002.  The 
development  of  human  resources  is  considered  a  crucial  part  of  the  Government’s  overall 
development policy. This is reflected in the Government’s commitment to  “Education for All,” 
which includes a 50% improvement in the level of adult literacy by 2015. The proposed project 
will  also  build  on  and  strengthen  ADB’s  ongoing  support  for  employment-oriented  skills 
development and microfinance.1  
 
2.  The ADB Fact-Finding Mission visited PNG on 17–26 February 2003.2 The Mission visited 
the provinces of Eastern Highlands, East Sepik, Enga, and Madang and consulted with a wide 
range of stakeholders. An information session for members of parliament provided the Mission 
with  the  opportunity  to  present  the  findings  to  high-level  political  decision  makers.  The 
Government has agreed with the TA goals, purpose, scope and implementation arrangements, 
cost and financing arrangements, and terms of reference. The TA framework is in Appendix 1, 
and  the  summary  initial  social  and  poverty  analysis  is  in  Appendix  2.  The  Government 
reconfirmed its strong interest in and support for the TA and highlighted its timeliness.3  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  PNG is lagging far behind other Pacific countries in achieving most of the Millennium 
Development Goals (MDGs).4 After 25 years of political independence and some economic and 
social progress, a large percentage of the PNG people remain poor. Some MDG indicators reflect 
deterioration,  particularly  those  for  health,  while  education  and  gender  equality  show  little 
progress and are far from achieving their targets by 2015. Enrollment ratios at all levels are low, 
with completion rates for primary schools reaching only 49%. Difficult access and long distances 
to educational facilities in rural areas have been cited as important reasons for low ratios.5 
 
4.  A major concern in the development process of PNG and a consequence of the low 
enrollment and completion ratios is the low literacy rate, particularly among women, in rural areas 
and in the highland regions. On average, 51.9% of adults aged 25 years and above are illiterate, 
ranging from the highest illiteracy rate of 72.2% among women in rural areas in the highland 
province of Enga to the lowest illiteracy rate of 5.3% among women in the island province of 
Manus. A significant gender gap exists, with literacy levels of women being 14% lower than those 
of men. However, the gender gap is less noticeable in youth literacy (15–24 years) and has 
increased to 10%.  
 
5.  Literacy in PNG has a very unique dimension, which has 5.5 million people, PNG is one of 
the most linguistically and culturally diverse nations. PNG has more than 830 languages, the

majority of which are unwritten. Alphabets for most of these vernacular languages, which are 
fundamentally different from each other, have yet to be developed. Some languages are spoken

communication; they are essential to cultural identity.  
 
6.  Adult literacy is considered by all major stakeholders an essential tool for community 
development and poverty alleviation. The ability to read and write empowers community people to 
participate actively in the development process. The ability to read information and news on 
various topics enhances the understanding of economic and social interrelations and opens new 
avenues to apply appropriate technologies and to generate additional income. Literate mothers 
are able to read health instructions; literate community members will improve their opportunities 
by interacting with public authorities on legal, environmental, and other relevant issues. 
 
7.  Universal “basic education” as defined in the National Education Plan focuses on children 
and  youth.  Basic  adult  education  and  literacy  training  is  considered  outside  of  the  formal 
education  system  and,  hence,  does  not  fall  under  the  responsibility  of  the  Department  of 
Education  (DOE).  One  source  of  confusion  among  literacy  implementers  has  been  the 
uncertainty over which government department has the responsibility for literacy and nonformal 
education. In 1986, the Government transferred responsibility for nonformal education from DOE 
to the Department of Home Affairs and Youth, which was later renamed the Department of Social 
Welfare and Development (DSWD). In 1990, the responsibility was transferred back to DOE and 
the National Literacy and Awareness Secretariat (NLAS), which was created during the same 
year. In 1995, the Organic Law on Provincial Government was introduced, and states that 
“literacy is the responsibility of local-level governments (LLGs) and funds for literacy are sent to 
provinces to be used by LLGs.” However, low or no budget allocations show that literacy is not a 
priority of LLGs at present. In most provinces, neither sufficient staff nor adequate funds are 
available to promote literacy programs. LLGs’ awareness about the value of basic education and 
literate communities is extremely poor. 
 
8.  In 2000, the National Literacy Policy was endorsed. The policy determines that DOE is the 
lead agency for nonformal education. The policy assumes that the technical know-how and the 
capacity to provide guidance in teacher training, curriculum development, material production, 
and awareness creation is available at provincial, district, and LLG levels. The reality is rather 
different and does not confirm this assumption. Public support for promoting adult literacy was 
rated poor. Overlapping roles and responsibilities of major stakeholders and lack of funds, 
qualified staff, and/or technical expertise aggravate this situation. In 2002, DSWD's mandate was 
expanded with the endorsement of the National Executive Council. The new policy states that 
DSWD is the focal point for the informal sector, which includes nonformal education.  
 
9.  Nongovernment organizations (NGOs) and churches have assumed the major role in 
supporting  literacy  programs  in  PNG  due  to  (i)  the  absence  of  a  systematic  coordination 
mechanism  linked  to  the  formal  education  system;  (ii)  the  lack  of  detailed  clarifications  of 
responsibilities among communities, and provincial and national government agencies promoting 
adult  literacy;  and  (iii)  insufficient  provision  of  funds  for  literacy  programs.  However, the 
capacities of NGOs and churches promoting adult literacy are limited, hence slow progress in 
improving literacy rates is inevitable under the current circumstances. 
 
10.  Most of the adult literacy programs in PNG are community-driven. The success and the 
quality of adult literacy programs depend very much on the commitment of communities and the 
engagement and qualification of community teachers. Over 2,000 community-based adult literacy

3
sites exist in PNG.6 Community ownership is essential for the sustainability of adult literacy 
programs.  Community  commitment  may  range  from  building  classrooms  and  compensating 
volunteer  teachers  to  fund-raising activities to provide learning materials and other support. 
Community-based adult literacy sites and programs are supported by NGOs, community-based 
organizations, churches, and government agencies mainly through teacher training, curriculum 
development, provision of learning material, awareness, and advocacy. No consistent system has 
been developed for adult literacy, and the quality and quantity of this assistance differ from 
province to province according to the potential of the support providers.   
 
11.  Adult literacy is no longer seen as an end in itself, but as means of gaining useful 
knowledge  and  skills  in  a  context.  Adult  literacy  programs  are  increasingly  responding  to 
economic needs. Functional literacy education is requested by adults in the communities to 
improve their income generation opportunities. However, communities in remote areas  with 
limited opportunities to earn cash and no reading materials in their language other than the Bible 
and songbooks do not see the value in being literate. To further the development of PNG and its 
people, and to reduce poverty in rural and urban areas,  the challenges associated with adult 
literacy must be addressed, particularly the lack of awareness and appreciation for literacy, lack 
of information about literacy providers and programs, insufficient teacher training and learning 
materials,  lack  clear  responsibility  among  government  agencies,  and  nonexistence  of  a 
coordinating mechanism among NGOs and between NGOs and the Government.   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
12.  The TA will assist the Government to (i) design a comprehensive strategy to further adult 
literacy in PNG; and (ii) prepare Literacy Is For Everyone (LIFE), an adult literacy project. 
Languages with orthographies, of which there are currently 129, will be the focus of the TA. The 
TA will have the following outputs: (i) design and pilot testing of (a) a national adult literacy 
campaign, and (b) a strategy to create awareness among the communities; (ii) a proposal for an 
amended national literacy policy clarifying roles and responsibilities at all levels of government; 
(iii) an outline for an institutional capacity building strategy for core divisions and departments 
responsible for adult literacy; (iv) the design of an information system on adult literacy; (v) the 
design of a trainer and teacher training system; (vi) pilot testing of new methods and materials to 
further adult literacy; and (vii) a proposed project design. The TA will be implemented in four 
provinces: Eastern Highlands, East Sepik, Enga, and Madang and will target communities in 
remote areas and women on a pilot basis.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  Output 1.  DSWD and NLAS, supported by an international consultant, will implement the 
following activities. (i) A stakeholder workshop will be conducted to determine the scope of the 
national awareness campaign targeted at decision makers. (ii) A national marketing company will 
be contracted to design and run the campaign for  3 months. (iii) Parliamentary information 
sessions at the national level and seminars with LLGs will be used to generate understanding of 
and support for adult literacy. (iv) Provincial workshops will be held, with adult literacy providers  
focusing  on  determining  suitable  pilot  activities  for  how  best  to  generate  interest  in  the 
communities.  (v)  The  provincial  focal  points  for  adult  literacy,  in  cooperation  with  literacy

providers, will carry out two pilot activities in each province .7 Provincial community awareness 
strategies will be designed based on the results of the pilot activities.  
 
14.  Output 2.  The second output focuses on the institutional arrangements and seeks to 
clarify the roles and responsibilities of government at all levels. Following an analysis of the 
weaknesses of the current policies and directives, a series of provincial and national workshops 
with government agencies  will  be  held  to  clarify  and  reach  agreement  on  responsibilities; 
channels  of  communication;  and  linkages  between  national,  provincial,  district,  and  local 
governments. Nongovernment stakeholders will be engaged in a further series of discussions to 
develop suitable coordinating mechanisms with Government and among themselves.  
 
15.  Output 3.  The institutional capacity of the Community Development Division at national 
and provincial level, NLAS, and literacy focal point divisions/organizations at provincial level will 
be  assessed.  Initial  training  measures  of  selected  staff  are  aimed  at  creating  a  better 
understanding  of  community-driven  development  including  adult  literacy  training.  Output  3 
concludes with the joint design of a capacity building strategy with human resources development 
plans.  
 
16.  Output 4.  An information system on adult literacy will be designed, in cooperation with 
NLAS, by a specialist in information management in education.  After sources of information are 
identified, a workshop will be conducted with key literacy organizations, NLAS, and provincial 
focal points to determine the scope of the data base and the type of data to be collected, and to 
reach agreement on the data collection process. After the first stage of data collection, a training 
course will be conducted  on data entry and management and a strategy on the maintenance of 
the data base and a performance management system will be agreed upon with the provincial 
focal points.   
 
17.  Output 5. The Summer Institute of Linguistics (SIL) will be engaged to lead a working 
group  of  teacher  training  organizations  in  cooperation  with  NLAS.  The  working  group  will 
exchange information and experience on teacher training and jointly determining the necessary 
content of (i) multiplier/core trainer training, (ii) teacher training, (iii) in-service training, and (iv) an 
accreditation system. SIL will assemble 10 kits for testing by SIL's trainee teachers. Based on the 
evaluation of the kit, a prototype will be developed including specifications and costs.  
 
18.  Output  6.    Brainstorming  sessions  at  the  provincial  level  with  NGOs  and  churches 
involved in adult literacy training, will be used to identify new methods and materials currently not 
applied in PNG. Examples could include work place literacy programs tested with larger gold 
mining operations in rural areas, newsletters and brochures in areas where the Bible and song 
books are the only written materials available, easy readers and short stories to test the interest 
in leisure reading, and radio and tape-recorded programs using solar-powered equipment to 
support community literacy programs in remote areas. An assessment of these activities’ impacts  
will form the basis for developing a strategy for replication. 
 
19.  Output 7.  A design will be made for the proposed ensuing loan project. The design will 
incorporate the outcomes of the outputs 1-6 and will include social and poverty assessments, and 
gender financial, economic, and institutional analyses.  
 
                                                 
7 The focal points and divisions are (i) the Council of Women in East Sepik Province, (ii) the Division of Education in the 
provinces of Madang and Enga, (iii) and the Division of Community Development in Eastern Highlands Province.

C.  Cost and Financing  
20.  The cost of the TA is estimated at $780,000 equivalent, of which $380,000 is the foreign 
exchange  cost  and  $400,000  equivalent  is  the  local  currency  cost.  The  Government  has 
requested ADB to finance $600,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost and 
$220,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed by ADB on a grant basis 
from the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Government will provide 
counterpart staff, domestic staff travel, office, and communication facilities amounting to $180,000 
equivalent in local currency. The TA will finance (i) an adult literacy awareness campaign, (ii) 
DSWD’s  human  resources  capacity  building,  (iii)  development  of  the  training  concept  and 
production  of  training  materials,  (iv)  a  series  of  national  and  provincial  workshops  and    a 
conference, (v) computer hardware and software and a prototype trainer kit, and (vi) international 
consulting services. Procurement under the TA will be in accordance with ADB’s procurement 
guidelines. Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 3. The Government has been advised that 
the approval of the TA does not commit ADB to financing any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  DSWD will be the Executing Agency for the TA. Implementation will be carried out in 
cooperation with NLAS, and the focal points for adult literacy at the provincial level. DSWD will 
set up a project management unit with qualified counterpart staff, and will provide office space, 
and transport and communication facilities. DSWD and NLAS will work on a day-to-day basis with 
the team of international consultants.  
 
22.  The TA will require 15.5 person-months of international individual consultants specialized 
in  (i)  education  policy  and  organizational  development  (the  team  leader),  (ii)  community 
awareness and social mobilization, (iii) information management in education, (iv) participatory 
planning, and (v) other specific areas as required8 (for 2 person-months). The outline terms of 
reference are in Appendix 4. The TA will be implemented over a period of about 16 months (May 
2003–September 2004). The team leader will submit  (i) an inception report, 4 weeks after 
commencement of the assignment; and (ii) a draft final report, 2 weeks before, and a final report, 
2 weeks after, the participatory planning workshop, incorporating the findings of the team. SIL9 
will be directly contracted to design the teacher training, in-service training, and accreditation 
system, and to develop a prototype teacher kits. The expected TA completion date is September 
2004.  The  consultants  will  be  selected  and  engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Papua New Guinea for preparing the Literacy is for Everyone Project, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board

The  Government  is  committed  to  addressing  social  and 
economic equity related issues through the implementation 
of  the  National  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy.  Poverty 
reduction  is  a  primary  goal  of  the  Medium  Term

B.  Poverty Analysis        Proposed Classification: ConsumerPrice Index  
1. What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
While national and regional poverty lines have been established, additional information will be collected to determine 
the incidence of nonfinancial poverty. This will focus on access to basic services and participation in the decision 
making processes at the village level and local level government. 
 
In a 1999 report, the World Bank assessed poverty and access to basic services. This was followed by PPA  funded 
by the Asian Development Bank (ADB), which commenced in 2001. The results of the PPA were used as the 
foundation of the National Poverty Reduction Strategy. Both rural and urban poverty is reflected in terms of lack of 
development in four broad areas: (i) cash (income generating opportunities including employment), (ii) education, (iii) 
health and hygiene, and (iv) infrastructure (access to roads and transport).  
 
In summary, most Papua New Guineans, especially women, are suffering increasing hardship due to the prolonged 
recession and continued lack of income-earning opportunities. (The term “poverty” is considered derogatory in the 
Melanesian context. Poverty is thus characterized in terms of lack of access to services and income-generating 
opportunities.) People employed in the formal sector have had their real incomes decline; and most people have 
experienced diminish opportunities for income-generation. Between 1996 and 2002, the number of Papua New 
Guineans living below the national poverty line is estimated to have doubled. The poverty headcount index was 
39.6% in 2002. An estimated 70% of the population, or 3.7 million Papua New Guineans, now live on less than $2 per 
day, up from 54% in 1996. The key factor underlying the increase in poverty over the last 5 years has been the 
continued failure of growth. 
 
Poverty is overwhelmingly rural. Of the poor, 94% live in rural areas, and 75% of the poor live in the Sepik, North 
Coast, and Highlands regions. Poverty is highest in female-headed households and in households dependent on 
cocoa, copra, fishing, and hunting-gathering. The most vulnerable groups are female-headed households, female 
youth, and the elderly. Rural-urban income disparities are widening, as are disparities between communities within 
and outside the immediate surroundings, and isolated resource projects (eg., mines, plantations). Households with 
wage  employment  in  the  formal  sector  have  a  17%    incidence  of  poverty,  compared  to  those  engaged  in 
agriculture/cash-crop production (44%). Inequality in Papua New Guinea (PNG) ranks among the highest in East Asia 
and the Pacific; Gini coefficient in PNG is 0.46. 
 
High levels of illiteracy coincide with high levels of poverty. The Momase region, which comprises East and West 
Sepik, Madang, and Morobe province, accounts for almost 36 percent of the poor in PNG and 29% of the population 
with an average literacy rate of 51%.  The Highland region (Eastern, Western and Southern Highlands, Enga, and 
Chimbu province), with about 40 percent of the population, accounts for 38 percent of the poor and an average literacy 
rate of 42%. The literacy rate among women is on average 14% lower then men.  
 
The selection of  the pilot provinces  – East Sepik, Madang, Eastern Highlands and Enga  – is based on the 
combination of high poverty incidence and high illiteracy rates. It is anticipated that more than 50% of the 
beneficiaries live below the poverty line. The design will focus on poverty beneficiary-specific interventions and will 
therefore ensure that the poor will reap the majority of the benefits.
